data.text: Contents
Transport of Patient Identifiable Items, Goods, Equipment and Medication ............... 11
Introduction
As a large NHS organisation, Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) has multiple sites spread across Essex serving a vast community of staff and patients that must travel to our premises.
With these geographical challenges in mind, it is necessary to ensure that a clear policy is in place to outline transportation arrangements for people and goods.
This policy provides a clear outline of eligibility criteria for the use of taxis specifically and necessary arrangements for booking taxis and couriers.

It must be recognised that pending the alignment of the non-emergency patient transport service across MSE, this policy must be read in conjunction with other transportation policies that cover the non-emergency ambulance services.
Scope

This policy outlines the provision of courier and taxi services for transportation of staff, non-emergency patients, items and equipment or critical medication that is required to be transported across sites, to other local NHS organisations and directly to patient's place of residence – on an ad-hoc or planned basis. The purpose of this policy is to ensure there is:
An appropriate, effective and economical use of taxis and couriers through adherence to the protocols
A planned courier service in place for the transportation of goods
Definitions

table_items.text: A nominated person that has the authority to approve the use of taxis and courtiers to transport patient or goods.
Hire vehicle (car or van) used to convey goods between locations determined by the requester.
Hire vehicle (saloon, people carrier and/or wheelchair accessible) used to convey passengers or goods between locations determined by the requester.
An item that has personal patient details displayed that can identify a patient specifically.
A medicine where next administration is not crucial to patient care, but should be continued at the earliest opportunity the
following day. In the context of this policy, this means the next supply of medication can be sent or collected the following day.

An essential medicine where timeliness of administration is crucial. In the context of this policy, this means the patient MUST receive a dose of medication (on grounds of patient safety and risk of harm) before it can be collected in person from the hospital.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Quality Governance Committee monitors compliance issues that may relate to the quality of service that transports staff, patients or goods.

Chief Executive has overall responsibility as the accountable officer ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.

Senior Director of Estates and Facilities ensures the Trust has an effective policy on the acceptable usage of courier and taxis for Trust business and their Authorising officers are responsible for ensuring that all staff are aware of and adhere to this policy and any associated local procedures.
Pathology Lead is responsible for the management of the Pathology First contract and subsequent sub-contractor courier services

Associate Directors and Head of Services are responsible for ensuring that appropriate staff are nominated to act as Authorising Officers and to ensure they adhere to this policy and any associated local procedures.

MSE Transport Manager is responsible for the management of internal transport fleet services across MSE and ensuring that resources and procedures are in place to deliver the courier services across MSE sites.

Head of Customer Services is responsible for the management of switchboard and general office services and ensuring that resources and procedures are in place to deliver the taxi booking service at Southend and Broomfield out of hours.
Patient Transport Co-ordinator (Mid) is responsible for the management of the non-emergency patient transportation services at Broomfield Hospital.
All staff
All employees of the Trust are responsible for ensuring that any couriers or taxis they request on account meet the relevant criteria described in section 6 and have been appropriately authorised.
Courier and transport services
Planned services
The MSE Transport department provides an internal transport fleet that has scheduled collections and deliveries across MSE site and local GPs and hospitals within Essex.

5.1.1 In addition, the Pathology Department provides a contracted courier service for the cross site transportation of specimens and bloods and emergency blood bikers for Transporting blood for transfusion.
5.1.2 Shuttle buses are provided across Southend Hospital and Britannia Park offices and between Basildon Hospital and Brentwood Hospital
Ad-hoc services

Courier and Taxi services are used within MSE on an ad-hoc basis for transporting staff, patients and a wide of range of items, including, but not limited to medical records, pharmaceutical items, furniture, equipment, specimens and post.
5.2.1 Taxis are used to transport non-emergency patients only and staff where required under specific circumstances as outlined under section
5.2.2 Internal Transport Fleet is also used to transport items at required which are managed by the MSE Transport Department.
5.2.3 Below summaries how staff, patients (non-emergency) and goods are transported across MSE sites and Essex.

table_items.text: Person or goods to be Transported
Non Critical Medication (see definition in section 3)

data.text: Staff transport
Eligibility and authorisation
Requests for staff to travel by taxi must meet one or more of the following criteria:-
Called to attend site urgently (on call) or in exceptional circumstances at management discretion - public transport/staff's own transport is unsuitable or unavailable
Urgently required to attend health care premises off site in exceptional circumstances at management discretion - public transport/staff's own transport is unsuitable or unavailable
Require to travel between health care premises sites as part of their working pattern and authorised by service manager- public transport/staff's own transport is unsuitable or unavailable
Required to transport staff and/or equipment for assessment in patient's home
Visiting patient's home for assessment, treatment or post discharge visit when staff's own transport is unsuitable or unavailable

Required to escort a patient transferring to another hospital by ambulance where the ambulance journey is one way and to return by public transport is either not practical (e.g. need to return medical equipment) or would entail excessive risk or delay to the staff member
The Guaranteed Ride Home scheme under the travel plan can book a taxi when an employee shares a vehicle with has left the site for any unforeseen reason, leaving them without transport home.

6.1.2 Taxis will not be provided for staff for routine journeys to and from work or to attend courses or conferences. Staffs are expected to make their own arrangements using private or public transport. Taxis for private or personal use must never be booked on account. Any member of staff found to have done so will be subject to disciplinary procedures and any cost relating to the journey will be recovered from the individual. Repeated abuse will result in a referral to counter fraud services and could result in disciplinary action up to and including dismissal.
6.1.3 Claims for reimbursement of public transport costs or mileage should be made in accordance with the Travel and Subsistence Expenses Claims Policy.

6.1.4 In certain circumstances, e.g. Christmas/New Year period or when adverse weather procedures are in force, taxis may be used to facilitate Trust staff travel to and from work while there is a reduced or no public transport services. This will be at the discretion of the relevant budget holder/service lead and staff will be required to evidence that they are normally reliant on public transport to attend work.
Booking taxis for staff
When booking taxis, the above criteria must be met in order to proceed with the following information provided at the time of booking:
Below outlines the process to book staff taxis across MSE.

table_items.text: Broomfield, Braintree, St Peter's and satellite sites
Basildon, Brentwood, St Andrew's and Orsett and satellite sites

data.text: Shuttle buses
A free shuttle bus service is provided for all staff travelling between: Southend Hospital and Britannia Park
Transport is also available for staff working on Bayman and Thorndon Wards at Brentwood Community Hospital.
Patient taxis

The Trust is not responsible for the commissioning or provision of patient transport. Patient transport is provided within the NHS in cases of medical need and as per local Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) criteria.

7.1.1 East of England Ambulance Service provides a service for eligible patients requiring transport for outpatient appointments, admission to or discharge from hospital, or transfer to other hospitals for continuation or upgrade of care. This service is directly funded by the CCGs and eligible patients with medical need for transport should be referred accordingly.
7.1.2 This policy refers to the use of taxis for patients only and not planned non- emergency ambulance services - please refer to Non-Emergency Transport Policy.
Eligibility and authorisation
A taxi should only be requested to transport a patient due to the following contingencies:

The East of England Ambulance Service is unable to assist with request due to short notice e.g. urgent follow up appointment, hospital booking error, and provided appropriate authorisation has been obtained
An assessment has been made that patient requires specific support on discharge which is authorised to escort the patient home by taxi if appropriate.
Transport is required outside the operating hours of the patient transport service e.g. vulnerable patient discharged from A and E after midnight and has been duly authorised.
7.2.1 To travel by taxi the patient must be assessed by clinical staff as meeting these criteria:
Medically fit to do so
Escorted where necessary (blind, confused, memory loss etc.)
Dressed appropriately in outdoor clothes
Accompanied by a responsible adult (normally parent/guardian) if under the age of 16
Able to travel by standard wheelchair. Bariatric wheelchairs cannot be transported in these vehicles as they will not fit into the standard fixings.

7.2.2 Patient transport is not provided on economic grounds. With pre-planned discharge every effort must be made to arrange for a friend or relatives to collect the patient through advance planning. If an inpatient has no medical need for transport but states they have no way of getting home, advice should be sought from the Discharge Team or Clinical Site Management out of hours based on assessment
criteria which include taking into account patient safety, availability of alternative transport locally and individual patient needs.

7.2.3 Where the patient is to be escorted by staff, e.g. for rehab or discharge home visit assessment, separate outward and return journeys should be booked to avoid unnecessary and costly waiting time, unless the destination is remote from the hospital and staff are likely to be unreasonably detained as a result.
7.2.4 In order to ensure that a robust assessment has been made to transport a patient by taxi, these will not be booked without appropriate authorisation by one of the following:
Clinical Site Co-ordinator
Discharge Co-ordinator
Duty Matron
Booking taxis for patients
When booking taxis for patients, the above criteria must be met in order to proceed with the following information provided at the time of booking:
Below outlines the process to book patient taxis across MSE

table_items.text: Broomfield, Braintree, St Peter's and satellite sites
Mon-Fri 08:00 – 16:00 Transport Coordinator Ext. 6880 or bleep #6555 2803
Sat and Sun 08.00-20.00 Discharge Lounge –Ext. 5160 or bleep #6555 2803
Sat and Sun and out of hours Via Switchboard
Basildon, Brentwood, St Andrew's and Orsett and satellite sites

data.text: Cancellation of taxis

In the event that a pre-booked taxi needs to be cancelled, at least 30 mins notice should be given wherever possible to enable timely notification to the taxi provider and avoid the cost of an ‘aborted' journey.
Transport of patient identifiable items, goods, equipment and
medication

Where there is a need for goods to be transported outside of existing services, e.g. due to size of goods, timescales, sites not visited, this request must be made to the Transport department who will arrange transportation of the goods.
Eligibility and authorisation
Authorised requests for movement of goods equipment or patient property must meet one or more of the following criteria:
Ad hoc urgent journey that cannot be undertaken within scheduled contracted courier run or using courier ad hoc service and that will otherwise impact on patient treatment or care.
Where patient property, cannot arrange own transport within reasonable time.
Transportation of patient identifiable items (i.e. health records)
For this, the authorising officer must ensure one or more of the following criteria are met:-
That where appropriate the patient or patient's family or friend have first been requested to collect the item from the hospital ward/dept. but are unable to do or within the necessary timescales.
Ad hoc emergency journey that cannot be undertaken within scheduled contracted courier run or using courier ad hoc service that will otherwise impact on patient treatment or care.
No approved secure priority service alternative is available, e.g. Royal Mail Special Delivery service, DX mail

8.3.1 It is the responsibility of the person requesting the external transport of Patient Identifiable Information to ensure the item is securely packaged and clearly labelled with recipients name and full delivery address in accordance with Trust policies.

8.3.2 Before booking a taxi the person requesting the transportation must phone the patient /place of delivery to ensure appropriate person will be available to receive the goods at the delivery address and provide clear instruction of what to do if unable to deliver to stated address, e.g. no reply on arrival.
Transportation of medication to patients residential address
For this, the authorising officer must ensure the following criteria are met:-

Medication is being transported as an exception to the Discharge Policy or is an outpatient critical medication authorised by the nominated clinical or pharmacy manager (or out of hours by Clinical Site Coordinator, Discharge Coordinator or Duty Matron).

8.4.1 Any medication transported out to a patient residential address must be securely packaged in a tamper proof bag or container. Tamper proof bags can include tamper proof security tape across opening of the bag and bags with integral seal that cannot be opened and re sealed.
8.4.2 Medication contents must not be visible through the bag or container. Double bagging may be necessary to facilitate this.
Deliveries containing controlled drugs

It is essential that controlled drug contents are not highlighted to the delivery driver to mitigate risk of diversion of these drugs. However, documentation held by the Trust must detail if a controlled drug is within the consignment for traceability.
Deliveries containing Fridge items
The outside of the delivery bag or container must be clearly marked stating that a fridge item is contained and must be refrigerated upon receipt.
Record keeping for medication deliveries

All medication deliveries must be recorded by the person requiring the delivery (i.e. the nurse from a ward) using appendix 1, medication delivery form. All sections required must be completed before sending with the medicines package to telephony.
8.7.1 All completed medication delivery form authorised by pharmacy, must be sent to the site pharmacy department the following day for audit trail.

8.7.2 All completed medication delivery forms authorised by non-pharmacy staff must be retained by telephony. These will be collected by the site pharmacy department on a weekly basis for purposes of audit.
Booking methods to transport goods

When booking any movement of goods across MSE, the below criteria must be met in order to proceed with the following information provided at the time of booking. If the goods being moved is of a significant size and additional resources are needed these will need to be arranged prior to the booking taking place
Below outlines the process to book ad-hoc couriers for transportation of goods across MSE.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the EFM Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the EFM governance Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)
